hedline.hl1: Home Sales Falter In the Suburbs

body.head.byline: By CARLYLE C. DOUGLAS AND MARY CONNELLY

block.p: LEAD: No one could predict how long the trend might last, or even say for sure that it was a trend, but a look at home buying in New York City's suburbs last week - which should have been the peak of the season - detected a lull. No one could predict how long the trend might last, or even say for sure that it was a trend, but a look at home buying in New York City's suburbs last week - which should have been the peak of the season - detected a lull. In communities where real-estate prices have more than doubled since 1980, sellers were lowering their prices and still waiting for buyers.

''For the moment,'' said Richard Palmer, regional vice president of the National Board of Realtors for New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania, ''the unsatiable demand for homes seems to be satisfied.''

Experts speculated as to the reasons: revisions in the Federal tax code, a recent jump in mortgage interest rates, and the relocation of many corporate employees to other parts of the country - in part because of the high cost of housing.
One would-be seller in Trumbull, Conn., Roger Sonstroem, put his theory this way: ''There is a limit,'' he said, ''to the number of people who can afford to pay $400,000 for a house.'' THE REGION
